taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013
IUCN Red List (Species Assessed for Global Conservation)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Are generally cryptic or solitary (Ref. 58006).  Inhabit heavily vegetated creeks, sloughs and roadside ditches.  Feed on microcrustaceans and other small, benthic invertebrates (Ref. 58006).  Oviparous, eggs are found in vegetation or just on the substrate (Ref. 58006).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: North America:  Waccamaw and Santee River drainages in North Carolina and South Carolina, USA.
dataObjects.references: Page, L.M. and B.M. Burr 1991 A field guide to freshwater fishes of North America north of Mexico. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 432 p. (Ref. 5723)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Eastern U.S.A.: Waccamaw and Santee river drainages, North Carolina and South Carolina.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 4; Dorsal soft rays (total): 8 - 12;  Analspines: 3; Analsoft rays: 5 - 8

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 3.3 cm TL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 58006)); max. reported age: 2 years (Ref. 58007)
references: Sandel, M. and P.M. Harris 2007 Threatened fishes of the world: Elassoma boehlkei (Rohde and Arndt 1987) (Elassomatidae). Environ. Biol. Fish. 78(4):289-290. (Ref. 58006)

Rohde, F.C., R.G. Arndt, D.G. Lindquist and J.F. Parnell 1994 Freshwater fishes of the Carolinas, Virginia, Maryland, and Delaware. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC. (Ref. 58007)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Mouth is terminal and upturned. Normally has 12-14 vertical bars along the body, alternating with iridescent interbars of approximately equal width. Sympatric species have head scales or humeral spots and ocular bars.
